review.title: Adapting Phrase-based Machine Translation to Normalise Medical Terms in Social Media Messages
review.abstract: Previous studies have shown that health reports in social media, such as DailyStrength and Twitter, have potential for monitoring health conditions (e.g. adverse drug reactions, infectious diseases) in particular communities. However, in order for a machine to understand and make inferences on these health conditions, the ability to recognise when laymen's terms refer to a particular medical concept (i.e.\ text normalisation) is required. To achieve this, we propose to adapt an existing phrase-based machine translation (MT) technique and a vector representation of words to map between a social media phrase and a medical concept. We evaluate our proposed approach using a collection of phrases from tweets related to adverse drug reactions. Our experimental results show that the combination of a phrase-based MT technique and the similarity between word vector representations outperforms the baselines that apply only either of them by up to 55%.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In fact, understanding the natural language of social media messages is a difficult task due to the lexical and grammatical variability of the language (Baldwin et al., 2013; 1http: / / www.dailystrength.org / 2http: / / twitter.comOConnor et al., 2014). Indeed, understanding the language of machines requires the ability to recognize when a phrase refers to a particular concept. Considering a variable length phrase, an effective system should return with the most similar meaning. A Twitter phrase "No way I'm gettin any sleep 2nite" could refer to the medical concept "insomnia" (SNOMED: 193462001) if we use the SNOMED-CT dictionary.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: Phrase-based MT models (e.g. (Koehn et al., 2003; Och and Ney et al., 2004) have proven effective in translating between languages, learning local term dependencies such as collocations, reorders, insertions, and deletions. Koehn et al. (2003) have shown that a phrase-based MT technique outperforms traditional word-based MT techniques significantly better than various benchmarks. In this paper, we adapt the phrase-based MT technique from Koehn et al. (2003) to the task of medical text normalization. In particular, we use the phrase-based MT technique to translate phrases from the Twitter language into formal medical language before translating the translated phrases based on the ranked similarity of their word vector representations based on word vector representations. sections.heading: 3 Medical Term Normalisation
sections.text: In Section 3.1 we discuss our adaptation of phrase-based MT to the normalization of medical texts. Section 3.2 presents our proposed approach to combining the similarity value of word vector representations with the adapted phrase-based MT technique.

sections.heading: 4.1 Test Collection
sections.text: To evaluate our approach, we use a collection of 25 million tweets about drug side effects. These tweets specifically refer to cognitive enhancers (Hanson et al., 2013) and antidepressants (Schneeweiss et al., 2010) that may have side effects. We use 201 ADR phrases and the associated SNOMED-CT concepts, commented on by a doctoral computer linguist. These phrases have been anonymized by replacing numbers, user IDs, URIs, locations, email addresses, data and drug names with appropriate tokens, such as NUMBER.

sections.heading: 4.2 Evaluation Approach
sections.text: We conduct 10-fold cross-validation experiments in which the Twitter phrases are randomly divided into 10 separate folds. We treat this task as a ranking task, where we aim to place the medical concept with the highest similarity value, e.g. calculated according to Equation (2), at the top. Therefore, we evaluate our approach using the Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR) metric (Craswell, 2009), which is based on the flip side of the ranking, which considers the first relevant concept in the ranking. Furthermore, we compare the significant difference between the performance achieved by our proposed approach and the baselines with the paired t test (p < 0.05).

sections.heading: 4.3 Word Vector Representation
sections.text: We use three different techniques, including onehot, CBOW and GloVe, to create word vector representations used in our approach (see section 3). Specifically, the vocabulary used to create the unified representation includes all the terms in the Twitter phrases and the descriptions of the SNOMED-CT target concepts. In the meantime, we create word vector representations based on CBOW and GloVe using the word2vec4 and GloVe5 implementations. We learn the vector representations from the collections of tweets and medical articles using a window size of 10 words. The tweet collection (referred to as Twitter) includes 419,702,147 English tweets referring to 11 drug names and 6 cities, while the medical article collection (referred to as BMC) includes all medical articles from the BioMed Central6. For both CBOW and GloVe, we create vector representations with vector sizes of 200 and 50 respectively.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: We have introduced our approach, which adapts a phrase-based MT technique to normalize medical terms in Twitter messages. We evaluate our proposed approach based on a collection of phrases from tweets associated with ADRs. Our experimental results show that the proposed approach exceeds an effective baseline by up to 55%. For future work, we intend to investigate the modeling of learned vector representation such as CBOW and GloVe within a phrase-based MT model in the normalization of medical terms.
